subject: CHEM

description: Introductory laboratory course covering basic synthetic and analytic techniques in organic chemistry. May be taken concurrently with CHEM S221 or subsequently. For college students only. Students wishing to take only the first or second of these courses (CHEM S222/S223)must obtain the permission of the Director of Summer Sciences. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,800. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Lab for Organic Chemistry
subject: CHEM

description: Offered Online. Survey of current understandings and treatment of autism from infancy through adulthood. Topics include etiology, diagnosis and assessment, treatment and advocacy, and social neuroscience methods. Focus on ways in which research findings are integrated into diagnosis and treatment practices. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Autism and Related Disorders
subject: CHLD

description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Classical Mythologies
subject: CLCV

description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. Introduction to Czech intellectual culture through contemporary film, fiction, art, and language. Emphasis on Kafka's influence on today's Prague. Works include films by Milos Forman (Fireman's Ball), Jan Kadar (Shop on the Main Street), Jan Sverak (Kolya), and Jan Hrebejk (Divided We Fall), and readings by Franz Kafka, Milan Kundera, Bohumil Hrabal, Vaclav Havel, and Arnost Lustig. A comprehensive introduction to basic Czech (no language prerequisites required) is an integral cultural part of the course. Students choose either FILM or CZEC credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Prague, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Course dates: June 28 - August 2.
title: In Prague Film and Fiction
subject: CZEC

description: Designed to introduce practical tools for directing, this course applies to anyone who is interested in working on technique as a director, whether as a career, for teachers directing a school play or for community theater productions. Topics include dramaturgy, script analysis, the director's work with the script, working with the actor, voice and speech techniques, and stage management organization. No formal training in directing necessary. Applicants should send a brief statement describing their background and areas of interest. A transcript is not required. Limited housing is available for this course; contact Yale Summer Session at 203.432.2430 for details. Tuition $750. Students must be available from 9:00 am to 10:00 pm Monday through Friday as well as Saturday afternoons and evenings and Sunday morning and afternoon. This intense course requires a full commitment of the student's time. The faculty reserves the right to add, extend, or adjust scheduled hours to accommodate the progress of the class. Course not open to pre-college students. Dates: July 16 - 25.
title: A Practical Approach to Directing
subject: DIR

description: Exploration and development of the fundamentals of the actor's craft based on the principles of Stanislavski. The course is actually a concise training program in which each student takes more than one class. The classes are in the following areas: (1) play analysis class, to understand what is to be acted; (2) acting class, to learn the application of basic acting techniques; (3) vocal production class, to improve vocal and articulation skills; (4) improvisation and mask class, to help free the imagination and to build confidence in spontaneous self-expression; (5) movement class, to strengthen the body and to encourage the use of the body for emotional expression; and (6) scene study class, to understand how the classes listed above come together when working on a scene. The instructors constitute a teaching staff of working professionals and are assisted by teaching associates giving the students individual attention. The summer drama program requires a full commitment of the student's time. Classes are held in the mornings, afternoons, and two evenings each week, Monday through Friday, with 26 to 28 classroom hours each week, 4 to 6 library hours each week, plus additional hours for individual tutorials and scheduled rehearsal time. Extra evening and Saturday morning sessions may be scheduled for group activities and additional classes. A single grade will be awarded for the course. Enrollment is limited. Complete applications must include a resume of relevant experience and a letter of recommendation from a drama teacher or other theater professional. Application deadline: May 1. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Yale Summer Conservatory for Actors
subject: DRMA

description: The structure and function of the human body, organization of body systems, and the study of regional anatomy. Modern body imaging methods. Fundamental dissection methods. Students will perform a complete dissection of a human cadaver. Meets departmental requirements for the major and is appropriate for students seeking to fulfill health profession prerequisites. Prerequisite: BIOL 101, 102, 103, and 104 or an equivalent or an equivalent full-year introduction to biology sequence. For college students and beyond. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Lab fee $600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Human Anatomy
subject: E&EB

description: Lecture, field, and laboratory based course that will explore the biodiversity-rich aquatic habitats of the Central Highlands (Appalachians, Ozark and Ouachita Mountains). Topics include the taxonomic diversity, ecology, biogeography, and evolutionary biology of aquatic animals (insects, crayfishes, mussels, and fishes). The course will include a two week field trip in the middle of the summer session to observe and sample riverine habitats in Tennessee, Kentucky, and Alabama. Prerequisite: BIOL 104 or equivalent. Recommended preparation: E&EB 225. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Course fee: $300. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Conservation & Biodiversity of Aquatic Habitats
subject: E&EB

description: Introduction to modern theories of decision-making under uncertainty by investors in financial markets. Analysis of expected utility theory and the Allais paradox, subjective expected utility and the Ellsberg paradox, portfolio theory, effcient markets, APT and behavioral economics. Prerequisites: ECON 115 and MATH 115 or their equivalents or scores of 5 on both AP Microeconomics and AP BC Calculus. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Introduction to Finance
subject: ECON

description: Same as Econ S115
title: Introduction to Microeconomics
subject: ECON

description: Same as Econ S115
title: Introduction to Microeconomics
subject: ECON

description: An introduction to basic macroeconomic concepts and theories, such as national income accounting, theories of growth, inflation, unemployment, business cycles, fiscal and monetary policy, banking, finance, and economic crises, with special emphasis on the recent financial crisis. Prerequisite: ECON 108, 110, 115 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Offered in both Session A: June 1 - July 3 (CRN: 30035) and Session B: July 6 - August 7 (CRN: 30036).
title: Introduction to Macroeconomics
subject: ECON

description: An introduction to basic macroeconomic concepts and theories, such as national income accounting, theories of growth, inflation, unemployment, business cycles, fiscal and monetary policy, banking, finance, and economic crises, with special emphasis on the recent financial crisis. Prerequisite: ECON 108, 110, 115 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Offered in both Session A: June 1 - July 3 (CRN: 30035) and Session B: July 6 - August 7 (CRN: 30036).
title: Introduction to Macroeconomics
subject: ECON

description: Offered Online. Basic probability theory, statistics, and linear regression. Methods of evaluation quantitative information; the use of data to answer quantitative questions in the social sciences. After ECON S115 and MATH 112 or equivalent. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: June 1 - July 3 (CRN: 30150) and Session B: July 6 - August 7 (CRN: 30151).
title: Econometrics and Data Analysis I
subject: ECON

description: Offered Online. Basic probability theory, statistics, and linear regression. Methods of evaluation quantitative information; the use of data to answer quantitative questions in the social sciences. After ECON S115 and MATH 112 or equivalent. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: June 1 - July 3 (CRN: 30150) and Session B: July 6 - August 7 (CRN: 30151).
title: Econometrics and Data Analysis I
subject: ECON

description: An introduction to the theory of multiperson decision problems and its application in economic analysis. Discussion of static and dynamic noncooperative games with particular attention to the notions of Nash equilibrium and sub-game perfect equilibrium. Prerequisite: two terms of introductory economics (ECON 115 and 116 or the equivalent). 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Game Theory
subject: ECON

description: Offered Online. An introduction to the theory of multiperson decision problems and its application in economic analysis. Discussion of static and dynamic noncooperative games with particular attention to the notions of Nash equilibrium and sub-game perfect equilibrium. Prerequisite: two terms of introductory economics (ECON 115 and 116 or the equivalent). For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Game Theory
subject: ECON

description: Offered Online. An introduction to the theory of multiperson decision problems and its application in economic analysis. Discussion of static and dynamic noncooperative games with particular attention to the notions of Nash equilibrium and sub-game perfect equilibrium. Prerequisite: two terms of introductory economics (ECON 115 and 116 or the equivalent). For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Game Theory
subject: ECON

description: Offered in Beijing, China. This course is part of the International Alliance of Research Universities' Global Summer Program. An overview of the Chinese economy, with attention to its rapid growth in the past two decades and its current challenges. The cultural and political background of the economy, China's market transition, manufacturing and financial sectors, foreign trade, foreign direct investment and technology transfer, and the reform of state-owned enterprises. Prerequisite: introductory economics. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Beijing, costs of room and board in Beijing, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Course dates: July 4 - August 2.
title: Introduction to the Chinese Economy
subject: ECON

description: The role of government in the economy and in our economic lives. Reasons for government intervention in the market economy and the impact of government expenditure programs and taxation systems on welfare and behavior. Tools of microeconomics applied to issues such as government response to global warming, the impact of redistribution and social insurance on individual behavior, school choice, social security vs. private retirement savings accounts, and government vs. private health insurance. Prerequisite: ECON S115 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Public Economics
subject: ECON

description: Offered in Paris, France. Parties engaging in economic exchange often organize their relationships through contracts and other private legal structures. The organization of exchange and the body of law and private institutions that govern and influence its structure. Substantive theoretical component and practical component, with on-site modules at the International Court of Commercial Arbitration in Paris. A comparative legal and institutional approach will be maintained throughout. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: MATH 112, ECON 121, or permission of instructor. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition: $7,000. Course Dates: June 29 - July 31.
title: Private Law and Contract Enforcement in the United States and France
subject: ECON

description: Offered Online. Corruption, a manifestation of the principal-agent problem, is an obstacle to economic efficiency. This course examines the economic, cultural, and political causes and consequences of corruption; cross-country comparisons of corruption levels; and examples of successful reforms and policies to combat corruption in bureaucracy and business. Students will complete a documented research project as part of the course. For college students and beyond. Prerequisite: ECON 108, 110, or 115, or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Causes&ConsequencesCorruption
subject: ECON

description: This is a course on efficiency,i.e., the First and Second Welfare Theorems, in simple general equilibrium models of competitive markets and market failures, where the welfare theorems do not hold, that is, externalities, public goods and monopoly pricing. In particular, we consider and compare the relative merits of the Kaldor-Hicks compensation principle in partial equilibrium analysis and the Pareto principle in general equilibrium analysis. Prerequisites: ECON 121 and MATH 112. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Welfare Economics and Equality
subject: ECON

description: Recent developments in international economics. Trade policy and market structure; the economics of trading blocs such as the EU and NAFTA; the economic consequences of continued U.S. external deficits; globalization and inequality; exchange rates, interest rates, and volatility; speculative capital flows and exchange rate policies; and financial crises and the prospects for the European Monetary Union. Prerequisites: Statistics or equivalents. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Topics in International Economics
subject: ECON

description: Examines how the nature of childhood has transformed from the early twentieth century to today. Key developments in the creation of modern childhood and adolescence including child labor, educational practices, children as consumer, and the emergence of the notion of the teenager. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Childhood and Adolescence in the Twentieth Century
subject: EDST

description: An introduction to information transmission and storage and their impact on society. Technological issues and trade-offs that affect the design of digital systems. Elementary circuits and computer logic; sensors and actuators; signal processing and design for data transmission; information transmission on the World Wide Web. Projects include analysis and design using Matlab or Excel. Intended for students in the humanities and social sciences and for freshmen considering a major in electrical engineering. No prerequisite other than a working knowledge of algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: The Digital Information Age
subject: EENG

description: Examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for non-science majors. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Science of Modern Technology
subject: ENAS

description: Covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Energy, Technology and Society
subject: ENAS

description: An introduction to the MATLAB and C programming languages for solving a variety of problems encountered in engineering, mathematics, and the natural sciences. General programming techniques, data analysis, numerical simulations, and transmission of data files between programs. Projects include processing microphone speech and digital images. prerequisites: MATH 115 or equivalent. Recommended preparation: previous programming experience. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Introduction to Computing for Engineers & Scientists
subject: ENAS

description: Basic theory of ordinary and partial differential equations useful in applications. First- and second-order equations, separation of variables, power series solutions, Fourier series, Laplace transforms. Prerequisites: ENAS 151 or equivalent and knowledge of matrix-based operations. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Ordinary and Partial Differential Equations with Applications
subject: ENAS

description: An introduction to academic argument and well-reasoned analysis, using a broad spectrum of nonfiction prose. Intensive instruction and practice in writing argumentative essays. Enrollment limited to 12. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Offered in both Session A: June 1 - July 3 (CRN: 30039) and Session B: July 6 - August 7 (CRN: 30040).
title: Writing Seminars I
subject: ENGL

description: An introduction to academic argument and well-reasoned analysis, using a broad spectrum of nonfiction prose. Intensive instruction and practice in writing argumentative essays. Enrollment limited to 12. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Offered in both Session A: June 1 - July 3 (CRN: 30039) and Session B: July 6 - August 7 (CRN: 30040).
title: Writing Seminars I
subject: ENGL

description: Close study of selected works of nonfiction prepares students to become critical readers and to apply professional strategies to their own writing. Readings from such authors as Joan Didion, Malcolm Gladwell, Maxine Hong Kingston, N. Scott Momaday, George Orwell, Brent Staples, Jonathan Swift, Henry David Thoreau, Tom Wolfe, and Alice Walker. Written assignments, involving frequent revision, include autobiography, portraiture, nature writing, cultural critique, and formal argument. Students who have not completed an introductory college-level writing course should take ENGL S114 instead. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Reading and Writing the Modern Essay
subject: ENGL

description: An introduction to the diversity and the continuity of the English language tradition through close reading of four poets from the fourteenth through the seventeenth centuries, Chaucer, Spenser, Shakespeare, and Donne. Emphasis on developing skills of literary interpretation and critical writing. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Major English Poets
subject: ENGL

description: An introduction to as well as an exploration of American literature from the nineteenth century to the present. We will ask many questions of these texts, not the least of which is "what do we mean when we say 'American?'" Given the wide range of the body of work that comprises American literature, however, we will also periodically ask in passing what we mean by "literature," so as to consider what roles the literary plays in creating and shaping the possibilities of social imagination, private and public discourse, as well as one's own identity. Emphasis on analytical reading, critical writing, and class discussions. Authors include Melville, Poe, Hawthorne, Whitman, Dickinson, Barnes, Toomer, H. Crane, W. C. Williams, L. Hughes, and M. Robinson. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Readings in American Literature
subject: ENGL

description: Conducted as a workshop, this course offers students the opportunity to write fiction and the particular sort of nonfiction that reflects and explores the narrative of their own lives. The focus will be on elements common to all storytelling, among them, character, narrative development, voice, and clarity of language and thought. Students may concentrate on a single genre, or, if they wish, experiment with both. Readings will include selections from contemporary American fiction and creative nonfiction. A brief writing sample in the course subject area is required and should be submitted with the online application. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Introduction to Writing Fiction and Creative Nonfiction
subject: ENGL

description: A study of ten comedies and romances, their festivities and their reservations. Extensive practice in writing critical essays. Students should come to the first class having read A Midsummer Night’s Dream. (The Signet edition is preferred.) Selections from filmed productions of the plays are screened semiweekly, and students are asked to attend a number of these screenings. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Shakespeare: Comedies and Romances
subject: ENGL

description: Study of three histories and seven tragedies at the pinnacle of Shakespeare's career. Focus on the source of each play's pathos and the nature of its poetic sublimity; some attention to performance and to the relation between the genres of history and tragedy. Extensive practice in writing short and medium-length critical essays. Students should come to the first class having read Julius Caesar. (The Signet edition, ordered through The Yale Bookstore, is preferred, but the Norton genre volumes are especially handsome substitutions; the Arden single play editions are more than acceptable if their price is not intimidating.) The regular course meetings will be supplemented by six evening screenings, and students are asked to attend at least four of these. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Shakespeare: Histories and Tragedies
subject: ENGL

description: Offered Online. This course is a study of Miltonâs major poetry. We will attend to the poetâs relation to the social and political struggles of the seventeenth century, and we will look in addition at his influence on literature and thought today. Our main texts are Miltonâs Paradise Lost and Samson Agonistes, and we conclude the term with a consideration of Philip Pullmanâs deeply Miltonic science fiction trilogy His Dark Materials. Students will watch or listen to pre-recorded lectures, and will meet online for biweekly seminar discussions. Satisfies pre-1800 requirement. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Milton
subject: ENGL

description: The social, cultural, and technological aspects of book publishing, production, and distribution from the fifteenth century to the present. Emphasis on three critical eras and technologies: the Renaissance and the hand-press book, the nineteenth century and the rise of mechanized printing and mass distribution, and the current digital age, when long-held assumptions about books, publishing, and reading will be examined and far-reaching questions about literacy, distribution, global access and equity, and even cognitive science discussed. The course is taught as a seminar through a series of firsthand encounters with manuscripts, rare books, prints, and other primary sources, from the medieval period through the present day. In addition, several class meetings will take place in other Yale collections that contain objects related to our study of the book as an instrument and agent of social change. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: From Gutenberg to Google Books: The Cultural History of Publishing, 1450 to the Present
subject: ENGL

description: Offered in Auvillar, France. Examines travel writing, surveying a wide range of works, from long-form place essays to destination articles, from travel memoir to adventure odysseys. Readings include, Paul Theroux, Ryszard Kapuscinski, Jan Morris, and Pico Iyer. How voyages lend travel writers structure: a natural beginning, middle, and end. Students are encouraged to take advantage of their geographic mobility for their assignments and tasked to find an innovative mode or vehicle of exploring their chosen place. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Auvillar, room and board costs in France, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Interview required. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Course dates: July 17 - August 14.
title: Travel Writing
subject: ENGL

description: An examination of British novels, drama, and poetry of the 1960s. Selected authors include Spakr, Beckett, Stoppard, Larkin, Plath, and Hill. Relevant selections of music, films, and television programs are also included. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: British Literature of the 1960s
subject: ENGL

description: Offered Online. In-depth reading and discussion of major twentieth-century American playwrights, including Eugene O'Neill, Thornton Wilder, Zora Neale Hurston, Tennessee Williams, Arthur Miller, Edward Albee, David Mamet, and Suzan-Lori Parks. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Modern American Drama
subject: ENGL

description: Study of drama, performance, and dance-theater created in the last ten years, with special attention to works produced in 2014 and 2015. Readings from both published and unpublished American and British plays, contemporary criticism, interviews, and essays by the artists themselves. Video of works created by companies such as Elevator Repair Service, Les Freres Corbusier, and the Nature Theater of Oklahoma. Will include attendance of productions in and around New York City. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Theater Now
subject: ENGL

description: An examination of creative and analytic responses to the changes in daily life brought about by the rapid proliferation of digital media and forms of communication. Both utopian and dystopian visions of digital society will be considered. Works to include nonfiction by Marshall McLuhan, Jaron Lanier, Clay Shirky, and Evgeny Morozov; fiction by Russell Hoban and Dave Eggers; and films such as 2001: A Space Odyssey, The Social Network, The Internship, and Her. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Digital Lives, Fiction and Nonfiction
subject: ENGL

description: Techniques of in-depth reporting, ranging from interviews and document research to journalistic storytelling; the evolution of "muckraking" in the United States; and the ethical, philosophical, and political issues raised by such work. Improvement of the students' practical research and narrative skills through weekly assignments and a term-long writing project. Designed equally for those with journalistic experience and for those with skills in other arenas. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Investigative Journalism
subject: ENGL

description: An advanced workshop for writers who want to review the performing arts for newspapers, magazines and other media. Weekly assignments to review screenings and performances, many of which will be part of New Haven’s International Festival of Arts and Ideas. Class trip to New York City to review a theatre production. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Reviewing Film, Theater, Music, and Dance
subject: ENGL

description: Introduction to contemporary philosophical debate about the nature of lies and deception. Definitions of lying and deception, including whether all lies necessarily aim to deceive; moral justifications for lying and deceit and their counterarguments; ways in which the moral arguments against deception of others can apply to self-deception. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Lies and Deception
subject: EP&E

description: Questions about human responsibilities for the environment. Wilderness protection, sustainability, preservation of species, the costs of fighting global warming, and humans' right to a healthy environment. Attention to analytical and argumentative skills required in legal and environmental advocacy. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Environmental Ethics
subject: EP&E

description: Causes of ethnic conflict and its most violent forms, including ethnic civil war. Critically reviews the dominant explanations of ethnic conflict and applies them to actual cases, including current examples of ethnic war, to arrive at an in-depth understanding of the problem and consider some of its solutions. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Ethnic Conflict
subject: EP&E

description: U.S. border and immigration policies at the national, state, and local levels from the colonial period to the present. The historical evolution of border and immigration policy; contemporary debates; the effects of shifting policy on immigrants of varying legal statuses. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: U.S. Border and Immigration Policy
subject: ER&M

description: Covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Energy, Technology and Society
subject: EVST

description: Explores the energy problems that will face the international community in the coming decades and the prospects for sustainable solutions. Emphasizes the importance of developing strategies to deal with the world's future energy supply and considers the challenges of limited natural resources and a growing world population. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Global Energy Strategies
subject: EVST

description: The development of international environmental policy and the functioning of global environmental governance. Critical evaluation of theoretical claims in the literature and the reasoning of policy makers. Introduction of analytical and theoretical tools used to assess environmental problems. Case studies emphasize climate, forestry, and fisheries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Global Environmental Governance
subject: EVST

description: Focus on relationships between gendered beings (both human and non-human) and the environments in which they live. Topics include feminist theories of nature and materiality, bodies and environmental toxicities, interspecies connections, and the sociopolitical contexts of environmental disasters. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Gender, Justice, and the Environment
subject: EVST

description: The development of international environmental policy and the functioning of global environmental governance. Critical evaluation of theoretical claims in the literature and the reasoning of policy makers. Introduction of analytical and theoretical tools used to assess environmental problems. Case studies emphasize climate, forestry, and fisheries. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Global Environmental Governance
subject: F&ES

description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. Introduction to Czech intellectual culture through contemporary film, fiction, art, and language. Emphasis on Kafka's influence on today's Prague. Works include films by Milos Forman (Fireman's Ball), Jan Kadar (Shop on the Main Street), Jan Sverak(Kolya), and Jan Hrebejk (Divided We Fall), and readings by Franz Kafka, Milan Kundera, Bohumil Hrabal, Vaclav Havel, and Arnos Lustig. A comprehensive introduction to basic Czech (no language prerequisites required) is an integral cultural part of the course. Students choose either FILM or CZEC credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Prague, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Course dates: June 28 - August 2.
title: In Kafka's Spirit: Prague Film and Fiction
subject: FILM

description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. Intensive, hands-on exploration of film history, theory and practice, offered in partnership with FAMU, the national film and television academy of the Czech Republic, Europe's top film school. Theory, tools, and techniques and practical skills--ÃÂÃÂfrom operating a 16mm film camera to recording dialogue to lighting a set--which students will apply in the production of a weekly film project. During the third week of the program, students will travel to the beautiful spa town of Karlovy Vary (Carlsbad) to attend the world-renowned Karlovy Vary International Film Festival. Instructors for the program will include Pavel Jech, the dean of FAMU, and Michal Bregant, the Director of the National Film Archive of the Czech Republic. The program includes a two-week mini course in Czech language and culture. All instruction is in English. Enrollment limited to 16. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Prague, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Yale Credit: Tuition: $3,600. 1 FAMU Credit: Tuition $3,750. Tuition is $7,350 total. Course dates: May 31 - June 27.
title: Cinematic Storytelling in Prague
subject: FILM

description: Offered in Paris, France. Introduction to French cinema and culture from 1915 to the present which focuses on the mystery, romance, youth and consumerism of Paris. Explores Parisian neighborhoods on city walks and visits two preeminent French cinema institutions (the Cinémathèque Française and the Institut Lumière). Films will include Breathless, La Haine, and Amélie. All readings will be in English with further optional readings in French. All films are subtitled in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Course dates: July 4 - August 8.
title: Paris and the Cinema
subject: FILM

description: Exploration of the contemporary Hollywood film industry. Introduction to the close analysis of film sequences. Central components of a Hollywood production, such as script, director, star, and genre. Aspects of the industry, including production, distribution, and exhibition. Ingredients of blockbuster success; why some films fail catastrophically. Case studies pair current films with historical ones. Includes two screenings per week. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: The Blockbuster and the Bomb
subject: FILM

description: A study of the interrelations among popular sport, cinema, television, radio, print, and social media. Explores topics of identity, commerce, and civics through contemporary texts (Hunger Games, Senna, Invictus), and introduces the history of sport in media culture. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Sports and Media
subject: FILM

description: Offered in Tokyo, Japan. A broad introduction to Japanese cinema and its interrelations with modern Japanese culture. Surveys the history of Japanese film from the silent era, through the golden ages of the 1930s and the 1950s, up until the present, with particular emphasis on recent decades and films that students can relate to the Japan they experience on the streets. Readings in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Tokyo, costs of room and board in Tokyo, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Course dates: June 27 - August 1.
title: Japanese Cinema and Culture
subject: FILM

description: The basic building block of a movie is a well-crafted scene. It instructs the screenwriter/filmmaker in a visceral and tangible way as to what does and does not work in production.This class focuses on the anatomy of a motion picture scene using the tools, craft, technical, and creative methods required to translate the written word to a visual language. Students learn filmmaking -- script analysis for production preparation: producing, budgeting scheduling, camera aesthetics and techniques, directing, working with actors, lighting, sound design, editing and media management. The course is a comprehensive collaborative journey using material previously produced and critically recognized in order to allow students to explore the contribution of the producer, director, cinematographer, sound designer, and editor. The emphasis is as much on process as product. Each student works collaboratively on multiple scenes over the course of the semester in each of the above mentioned crew positions. The pace of the course assumes some prior technical familiarity with digital HD cameras, field sound recording, competency with HD workflow and final cut non-linear editing: however, the course begins with detailed seminars in each of the crew positions before productions begin. The goal of the class is to go through a practical professional procedure of creating scenes from the perspective of key crew positions as if it were a complete motion picture, thus enabling the students to understand, absorb and solve their own work. Limited to 16 students. 2 Credits. Tuition: $7,000. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Filmmaking: The Anatomy of a Scene
subject: FILM

description: An examination of the key events and ideas that shape the modern motion picture business from financial, institutional, and historical standpoints. Topics include ways that the business has evolved in response to changes in technology, distribution, and competition; how the business dictates what ends up on screen; and relationships among studios, actors, agents, independent filmmakers, distributors, and the viewing audience. Industry practitioners discuss special topics. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Money and Media: The Business of Hollywood
subject: FILM

description: Eighteen films depicting some of the varied effects of war, especially the two World Wars, on individual combatants, civilians, occupied peoples and others not engaged in military action itself. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: The Cinema of War
subject: FILM

description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of fiction and nonfiction features. Topics will include: the Progressive Era, Jazz Age urban America, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate, Vietnam, September 11th, and the 2008 financial crisis. Emphasis will be placed on the manner in which the past is depicted in individual films and what the choice of subjects reveals about the directors' sociopolitical moment. This course seeks to expand students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture, and society. In-class screenings will include American films from a broad range of time periods and genres. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Film, Video, and American History
subject: FILM

description: Offered in Swaziland. Explores the intersection of global health and visual media. Focuses on global health issues such as HIV, TB, human rights, and violence in public health. Students learn filmmaking as a means for translating complex public health concepts into a format approachable by a general audience and create a short film on a selected global health topic. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Swaziland, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Course dates: June 20 - August 2.
title: Visual Approaches to Global Health
subject: FILM

description: A seminar and workshop in screenplay writing. Students learn the basics of the craft by reading existing scripts, looking at films from a writer's perspective, and writing a short screenplay. Additional hours of individual screenings required. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Screenwriting
subject: FILM

description: Examines crime dramas, reality television, news coverage, and crime documentaries. Analysis of how popular media shapes public views on criminality, law enforcement, violence, due process, and judicial responsibility. Pays attention to the historical relationship between media, crime, and the politics of race, class, gender, and sexuality. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Television and Crime
subject: FILM

description: 4 weeks in New Haven, 4 weeks in Paris. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for students with no previous study of French. Focuses on developing language skills, communicative proficiency, self-expression, and cultural insights through extensive use of authentic audio, video material, and field trips. Conducted entirely in un-simplified French. Daily classroom attendance, language laboratory work, and all field trips are required. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S120. Credit only on completion of FREN S120. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 credits. Tuition: $3,600. Course dates: June 8 - August 1
title: Elementary and Intermediate French I
subject: FREN

description: 4 weeks in New Haven, 4 weeks in Paris. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for students with no previous study of French. Focuses on developing language skills, communicative proficiency, self-expression, and cultural insights through extensive use of authentic audio, video material, and field trips. Conducted entirely in un-simplified French. Daily classroom attendance, language laboratory work, and all field trips are required. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S110. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. Tuition: $3,600. Course dates: June 8 - August 1
title: Elementary and Intermediate French II
subject: FREN

description: 4 weeks in New Haven, 4 weeks in Paris. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed to perfect students' skills in understanding spoken and written French and in speaking and writing. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for nonacademic use of French. Prerequisite: FREN 120, 121 or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S140. Credit only on completion of FREN S140. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,600. Course dates: June 1-July 25
title: Intermediate and Advanced French I
subject: FREN

description: 4 weeks in New Haven, 4 weeks in Paris. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed to perfect students' skills in understanding spoken and written French and in speaking and writing. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for nonacademic use of French. Prerequisite: FREN 130, 131, or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S130. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,600. Course dates: June 1-July 25
title: Intermediate and Advanced French II
subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. An advanced language course intended to improve students' comprehension of spoken and written French as well as their speaking and writing skills. Excursions to museums, movies, and theaters complement the reading of modern fiction and nonfiction texts. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition.
requirements: Prerequisite: after FREN 140, 145, or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit.
title: Advanced Culture and Conversation
subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. Intensive oral practice for advanced students. An introduction to contemporary French culture and current events while sharing day-to-day life with Parisians. In small groups, students conduct surveys and interviews, melding the techniques of ethnography and photojournalism. Classroom activities include students' presentation of their findings; discussions and debates based on readings of newspapers and other periodicals; films; songs; stories; and clips from French television. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Prerequisite: after FREN 150, 151, or equivalent proficiency. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Course dates: May 25-June 27
title: Advanced Culture and Conversation
subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France, with visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens, Beauvais, Rouen, Cluny museum, and discussion of accompanying historical, literary, and philosophical works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, Thibault de Champagne, Pseudo-Dionysius, Marie de France, Jacques de Voragine, Guibert de Nogent, and the anonymous Song of Roland, Quest for the Holy Grail, fabliaux, and courtly lyric. Core consideration of gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual and religious life of twelfth- and thirteenth-century France. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Conducted in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Course dates: July 4 - August 8.
title: Age of Cathedrals
subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of important works of literature, painting, sculpture, architecture, music, and the decorative arts in turn-of-the-century France (1870-1914). This course will acquaint students with the principal literary and artistic forms, social trends, political movements, scientific theories, and technological innovations of the Belle Epoque, with visits to museums, architectural monuments, theater, and art nouveau cafes in Paris. Principal authors: Zola, Gide, Proust, Bergson, Apollinaire, Maupassant, Mallarme, Colette, Alain-Fournier, Barbey D'Aurevilly, Simmel, Jarry, and Feydeau. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Conducted in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Course dates: May 30 - July 4.
title: Belle Époque France
subject: FREN

description: The processes that shape Earth's environment through the interactions of rocks, soils, the atmosphere, and the hydrosphere. Field trips and practical sessions in the properties of natural materials. Topics include evolution of landscapes; hydrologic and tectonic cycles; extreme geologic events such as earthquakes, floods, volcanism, and landslides; society's economic dependence on natural materials such as soils, minerals, and fossil fuels; and human influences on the natural environment. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Earth, Dynamic Planet
subject: G&G

description: Covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Energy, Technology and Society
subject: G&G

description: The mutual influence of law and politics at the international level. Topics include the sources of international law, the participants, courts, dispute settlement, jurisdiction, and customary law. Readings on foreign policy making, international law, treaties, and international courts from the literature of United Nations bodies and of the International Law Commission. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Foreign Policy and International Law
subject: GLBL

description: Introduction to the international human rights regime. Analysis of tools used by actors to promote human rights in the international system. Origins of the regime and contested notions of human rights. Issues include genocide, torture, and the rights of women, children, and sexual minorities. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Introduction to Human Rights Theory and Practice
subject: GLBL

description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. Overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the 21st century. Students will also meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and have the option of home stays with Moroccan families. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Morocco, room and board costs in Morocco, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Course dates: June 27-August 1.
title: Society and Politics of North Africa
subject: GLBL

description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Berlin. An intensive, content-based language course that teaches linguistic skills through a variety of literary and nonfiction texts and film, with special emphasis on the culture and history of Berlin. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Berlin, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15 . Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with GMAN S140. Credit only on completion of GMAN S140. Prerequisite: GMAN 120 or equivalent. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,600. Course dates: June 1-July 25.
title: Intermediate German I
subject: GMAN

description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Berlin. An intensive, content-based language course that teaches linguistic skills through a variety of literary and nonfiction texts and film, with special emphasis on the culture and history of Berlin. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Berlin, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with GMAN S130. Prerequisite: GMAN 130 or equivalent. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,600. Course dates: June 1-July 25.
title: Intermediate German II
subject: GMAN

description: The nature, history, and possible meanings of dream experience, with reference to Sigmund Freud's Interpretation of Dreams. Works from film and literature about dreams and dreaming, as well as major texts in dream theory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: The Logic of Dreams
subject: GMAN

description: From the promise of beauty to the experience of literary seduction, the class will address the complex function and effects of the aesthetical regime. What constitutes the experience in the arts? And what separates our desires in the real world from the pleasures art promises us? Is there really a fundamental difference between low or even sexual desires and those higher forms that art can provide us with?  And is it true that dreaming is as close to suppression and wish fulfilment, as film is said to be? What does this tell us about our dreams - and about art? Apart from theoretical texts (including Freud, Jung, Fechner) class will treat painting (from Raffaello to Dali), Photography (from Man Ray to Jeanloup Sieff) and Literature (From Rousseau to Doeblin), as well as opera and film. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Psychological Disciplines and the Arts
subject: GMAN

description: Introduction to ancient Greek. Emphasis on morphology and syntax within a structured program of readings and exercises. Prepares for GREK S120. No prior knowledge of Greek assumed. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Beginning Greek: The Elements of Grammar
subject: GREK

description: Continuation of GREK S110. Emphasis on consolidating grammar and on readings from Greek authors. The sequence GREK S110, S120 prepares for GREK 131 or 141. Prerequisite: GREK S110 or equivalent. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Beginning Greek: Review of Grammar and Selected Readings
subject: GREK

description: The relationship between medicine, labor, and the market since the beginning of the nineteenth century, with a focus on the origins of the American public-private healthcare system. Topics include the professionalization of physicians, the regulation of the medical marketplace, the gendered politics of care, the emergence of a global pharmaceutical industry, the marketing of drugs and devices, inequality of access in healthcare, and the history of American healthcare reform. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Money and Medicine
subject: HIST

description: Examines how the nature of childhood has transformed from the early 20th century to today. Key developments in the creation of modern childhood and adolescence including child labor, educational practices, children as consumer, and the emergence of the notion of the teenager. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Childhood and Adolescence in the 20th Century
subject: HIST

description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of fiction and nonfiction features. Topics will include: the Progressive Era, Jazz Age urban America, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate, Vietnam, September 11th, and the 2008 financial crisis. Emphasis will be placed on the manner in which the past is depicted in individual films and what the choice of subjects reveals about the directors' sociopolitical moment. This course seeks to expand students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture, and society. In-class screenings will include American films from a broad range of time periods and genres. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Film, Video, and American History
subject: HIST

description: Mythologies of the Vikings including stories of Thor, Freya, Odin, Loki, and minor characters. Viking myths of the creation of the world and its end in context with mythologies of other religions. Considers various sources from historians, folklorists, literature scholars, and historians of religion to extricate fact from fiction. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3
title: The Myths of the Vikings
subject: HIST

description: The social, cultural, and technological aspects of book publishing, production, and distribution from the fifteenth century to the present. Emphasis on three critical eras and technologies: the Renaissance and the hand-press book, the nineteenth century and the rise of mechanized printing and mass distribution, and the current digital age, when long-held assumptions about books, publishing, and reading will be examined and far-reaching questions about literacy, distribution, global access and equity, and even cognitive science discussed. The course is taught as a seminar through a series of firsthand encounters with manuscripts, rare books, prints, and other primary sources, from the medieval period through the present day. In addition, several class meetings will take place in other Yale collections that contain objects related to our study of the book as an instrument and agent of social change. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: From Gutenberg to Google Books: The Cultural History of Publishing, 1450 to the Present
subject: HIST

description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. Overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the 21st century. Students will also meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and have the option of home stays with Moroccan families. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Morocco, room and board costs in Morocco, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Course dates: June 27-August 1.
title: Society and Politics of North Africa
subject: HIST

description: A survey of Western Europe from the late medieval period to the eighteenth century. Major topics include the Crusades, late medieval heretical movements, the Protestant and Catholic Reformations, the wars of religion, the seventeenth-century witch craze, and the rise of secularism and tolerance. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: From Crusade to Enlightnement: Medieval & Early Modern Europe
subject: HIST

description: The construction of madness and mental illness in Western thought and culture. The rise and fall of the asylum system; the development of psychoanalytic theory; twentieth-century medical practices; the antipsychiatry movement; patients' rights and contested diagnoses; portrayals of the mentally ill in society and popular culture; issues surrounding gender and sexuality; mental illness in colonial, post-colonial, and global context. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Cultural History of Mental Illness
subject: HIST

description: Examines the Cold War as a struggle for ideological and geopolitical preeminence, tracing its origins, stagnation, and unexpected end from the perspectives of three worlds: capitalist, socialist, and postcolonial. Sources include declassified documents, contemporary fiction and recent secondary reinterpretations, as well as films and field trips. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: The Cold War
subject: HIST

description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study from antiquity to modernity. Byzantine presence and the remnants of the Roman world; consequences of the schism between Rome and Constantinople; barbarian kingdoms and the medieval city-states; Ottoman incursions and millets; Renaissance and Baroque; beginning of nationalism and modern national integrations; national revolutions, fascism, communism, and post-communist conflicts; secularization of religion; genocide in post-Yugoslav wars. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Dubrovnik, room and board costs in Croatia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with SOCY S286. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,500. Course dates: June 28 - August 1.
title: History of Southeastern Europe
subject: HIST

description: Survey of the history of China, Japan, and Korea from the seventh century to the present. Focus on two separate empires: the Tang and Japanese. Attention to interactions among East Asian regions in the past and today. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Empires of East Asia
subject: HIST

title: Visual Approaches to Global Health
subject: HLTH

description: Art from 1970 to the present and recent historical precedents that have shaped current artistic practices. Topics include conceptual art, appropriation, institutional critique, video, installations, relational aesthetics, among others. Focusing mostly on work made in the United States and Europe, but also considers the emergence of a global art market through art fairs and biennials. Classes supplemented with visits to the Yale University Art Gallery. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Contemporary Art
subject: HSAR

description: Introduction to the art and archaeology of three Mediterranean sites buried by volcanic eruptions, with special attention to new discoveries and interpretations. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Buried Cities: Thera, Pompeii, Herculaneum
subject: HSAR

description: In-depth discussion of ten major works of Western art from the Renaissance to the modern era. Works selected both for their extraordinary qualities and for their capacity to represent a range of periods, places, media, themes, and functions. Includes visits to Yale's art museums to view corollary works of art; some attention to relevant poetry, literature, and film. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Ten Works of Western Art
subject: HSAR

title: Cultural History of Mental Illness
subject: HSHM

description: Offered Online. The changing meaning of the term "genius" from ancient Greece to the present. The nature of genius examined through the lives and working methods of exceptional individuals, including Mozart, da Vinci, Newton, Picasso, and Einstein. Topics such as nature vs. nurture, prodigy, concentration, and exceptional processing skills explored to define and establish markers for genius. Recent developments in neurobiology that may elucidate why some individuals possess extraordinary mental and artistic abilities. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Technology fee $85. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Brains of Genius: Mozart & Friends
subject: HUMS

description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Classical Mythologies
subject: HUMS

title: Belle Époque France
subject: HUMS

description: Representations of the human body in law and literature. The complex nature of how humans think about and give meaning to their bodies in relationship to themselves and to others. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Bodies in Law and Literature
subject: HUMS

description: The nature, history, and possible meanings of dream experience, with reference to Sigmund Freud's interpretation of Dreams. Works from film and literature about dreams and dreaming, as well as major texts in dream theory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: The Logic of Dreams
subject: HUMS

description: Offered in Rome, Italy. Designed as the logical complement and correlation to HUMS 444, this course will consider how Rome's contributions to Western thought are recorded in the very fabric of the city. Open to Yale students only. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Rome, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Prerequisite: HUMS 444. Enrollment limited, with preference to Humanities majors and juniors. For further information please please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Course dates: May 31- July 4.
title: Rome
subject: HUMS

description: Offered in Auvillar, France. Open to both Yale and non-Yale students from liberal arts and fine arts backgrounds with or without prior experience. STUDIO PRACTICE is an intensive study of painting and drawing focusing on the dynamics of the artist's studio practice of developing and constructing work. It is crafted for those who wish to study and experience the intimate process of personal idea imaging through the language of painting and drawing. Of great importance to the course is the development of strategies necessary for individual discovery, observation/analysis,and relational thinking. The residential program demands commitment, a strong work ethic and study within a 24/7 curriculum. Enrollment is limited to 15 participants. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Auvillar, room and board costs in France, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Interview required. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Course dates: May 31 - June 29.
title: Studio Practice in Painting and Drawing
subject: HUMS

description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France, with visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens, Beauvais, Rouen, Cluny museum, and discussion of accompanying historical, literary, and philosophical works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, Thibault de Champagne, Pseudo-Dionysius, Marie de France, Jacques de Voragine, Guibert de Nogent, and the anonymous Song of Roland, Quest for the Holy Grail, fabliaux, and courtly lyric. Core consideration of gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual and religious life of twelfth- and thirteenth-century France. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Conducted in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,000. Course dates: July 4 - August 8.
title: Age of Cathedrals
subject: HUMS

description: Must be taken in New Haven. May be arranged for currently enrolled Yale students in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology; Engineering and Applied Science; Geology and Geophysics; Chemistry; Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry; Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology; Physics; or any other science department sponsoring such programs. These programs are especially useful for juniors in providing them with actual research experience prior to application to graduate or professional schools. Students wishing to enroll must complete the regular application for Yale Summer Session. In addition, students must submit written permission of (1) the faculty sponsor, who should also supply a l- or 2-paragraph description of the research to be undertaken including the proposed starting and ending dates, (2) the Director of Summer Sciences, and (3) the director of undergraduate studies of the applicant's major department. Students taking Independent Research for 1 credit must work 35 hours a week for five weeks (either Session A or B); for 2 credits students must work 35 hours a week for ten weeks (both Session A and B). Students may receive academic credit only if they are not being paid for doing research, but they may work for credit in one 5-week period and for pay in the other. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session A: June 1 - July 3.
title: Independent Research in the Sciences
subject: IDRS

description: Must be taken in New Haven. May be arranged for currently enrolled Yale students in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology; Engineering and Applied Science; Geology and Geophysics; Chemistry; Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry; Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology; Physics; or any other science department sponsoring such programs. These programs are especially useful for juniors in providing them with actual research experience prior to application to graduate or professional schools. Students taking Independent Research for 1 credit must work 35 hours a week for five weeks (either Session A or B); for 2 credits students must work 35 hours a week for ten weeks (both Session A and B). Students may receive academic credit only if they are not being paid for doing research, but they may work for credit in one 5-week period and for pay in the other. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,600. Session B: July 6 - August 7.
title: Independent Research in the Sciences
subject: IDRS

description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Siena. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for first-year Italian students, combining language study at the elementary level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S120. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Credit only on completion of ITAL S120. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,600. Course dates: June 1 - July 25.
title: Elementary Italian I
subject: ITAL

An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for first-year Italian students, combining language study at the elementary level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S110.
